problems.title: Breach of Faith
problems.statementHtml:
You and your team have worked tirelessly until you have a sequence a1,a2,…,a2n+1 of positive integers satisfying these properties.

However, the people you worked with sabotaged you because they wanted to publish this sequence first. They deleted one number from this sequence and shuffled the rest, leaving you with a sequence b1,b2,…,b2n. You have forgotten the sequence a and want to find a way to recover it.

If there are many possible sequences, you can output any of them. It can be proven under the constraints of the problem that at least one sequence a exists.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains one integer n (1≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line of each test case contains 2n distinct integers b1,b2,…,b2n (1≤bi≤109), denoting the sequence b.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output 2n+1 distinct integers, denoting the sequence a (1≤ai≤1018).

If there are multiple possible sequences, you can output any of them. The sequence a should satisfy the given conditions, and it should be possible to obtain b after deleting one element from a and shuffling the remaining elements.

problems.title: Finding OR Sum
problems.statementHtml:
This is an interactive problem.

There are two hidden non-negative integers xx and yy (0≤x,y<2300≤x,y<230). You can ask no more than 22 queries of the following form.

After this, the judge will give you another non-negative integer mm (0≤m<2300≤m<230). You must answer the correct value of (m|x)+(m|y)(m|x)+(m|y).
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

Interaction

Two hidden integers xx and yy are chosen (0≤x,y<2300≤x,y<230). Note that xx and yy might be different for different test cases.

The interactor in this task is not adaptive. In other words, the integers xx and yy do not change during the interaction.

To ask a query, pick an integer nn (0≤n<2300≤n<230) and print only the integer nn to a line.

You will receive a single integer, the value of (n|x)+(n|y)(n|x)+(n|y).

You may make no more than 22 queries of the following form.

After you finish your queries, output "!" in a line. You will receive an integer mm (0≤m<2300≤m<230). Note that the value of mm is also fixed before interaction.

You must output only the value of (m|x)+(m|y)(m|x)+(m|y) in a line. Note that this line is not considered a query and is not taken into account when counting the number of queries asked.

After this, proceed to the next test case.

If you make more than 22 queries during an interaction, your program must terminate immediately, and you will receive the Wrong Answer verdict. Otherwise, you can get an arbitrary verdict because your solution will continue to read from a closed stream.

After printing a query do not forget to output the end of line and flush the output. Otherwise, you will get Idleness limit exceeded. To do this, use:

  • fflush(stdout) or cout.flush() in C++;
  • System.out.flush() in Java;
  • flush(output) in Pascal;
  • stdout.flush() in Python;
  • see the documentation for other languages.

Hacks

To hack, follow the test format below.

The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first and only line of each test case contains a single line with three integers x,y,mx,y,m (0≤x,y,m<2300≤x,y,m<230).
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test, the interaction proceeds as follows.

SolutionJuryExplanation
22There are 2 test cases.
In the first test case, x=1x=1 and y=2y=2.
0033The solution requests (0|1)+(0|2)(0|1)+(0|2), and the jury responds with 33.
1144The solution requests (1|1)+(1|2)(1|1)+(1|2), and the jury responds with 44.
!!11The solution requests the value of mm, and the jury responds with 11.
44The solution knows that (1|x)+(1|y)=4(1|x)+(1|y)=4 because of earlier queries.
In the second test case, x=0x=0 and y=0y=0.
0000The solution requests (0|0)+(0|0)(0|0)+(0|0), and the jury responds with 00.
!!11The solution requests the value of mm, and the jury responds with 11.
22The solution somehow deduces that x=y=0x=y=0, so it responds with (1|0)+(1|0)=2(1|0)+(1|0)=2.

Note that the empty lines in the example input and output are for the sake of clarity and do not occur in the real interaction.

problems.title: Binary Subsequence Value Sum
problems.statementHtml:
For a binary string∗∗ vv, the score of vv is defined as the maximum value of

F(v,1,i)⋅F(v,i+1,|v|)F(v,1,i)⋅F(v,i+1,|v|)

over all ii (0≤i≤|v|0≤i≤|v|).

Here, F(v,l,r)=r−l+1−2⋅zero(v,l,r)F(v,l,r)=r−l+1−2⋅zero⁡(v,l,r), where zero(v,l,r)zero⁡(v,l,r) denotes the number of 00s in vlvl+1…vrvlvl+1…vr. If l>rl>r, then F(v,l,r)=0F(v,l,r)=0.

You are given a binary string ss of length nn and a positive integer qq.

You will be asked qq queries.

In each query, you are given an integer ii (1≤i≤n1≤i≤n). You must flip sisi from 00 to 11 (or from 11 to 00). Find the sum of the scores over all non-empty subsequences†† of ss after each modification query.

Since the result may be large, output the answer modulo 998244353998244353.

Note that the modifications are persistent.

∗∗A binary string is a string that consists only of the characters 00 and 11.

††A binary string xx is a subsequence of a binary string yy if xx can be obtained from yy by deleting several (possibly zero or all) characters.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and qq (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105, 1≤q≤2⋅1051≤q≤2⋅105) — the length of the string ss and the number of modification queries, respectively.

The second line contains the binary string ss of length nn, consisting of characters 00 and 11.

The following qq lines each contain an integer ii (1≤i≤n1≤i≤n), indicating that sisi is flipped from 00 to 11 or from 11 to 00.

It is guaranteed that neither the total sum of all values of nn nor the total sum of all values of qq across all test cases exceeds 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output qq lines, each line containing a single integer — the required sum modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
For the first test case, after the first modification, we have s=110s=110. We can compute the sum of scores over all subsequences as follows:

IndicesSubsequenceScore
11100
22100
1,21,21111
33000
1,31,31000
2,32,31000
1,2,31,2,311000

Summing up: 0+0+1+0+0+0+0=10+0+1+0+0+0+0=1.

After the second modification, we have s=111s=111. We can compute the sum of scores over all subsequences as follows:

IndicesSubsequenceScore
11100
22100
1,21,21111
33100
1,31,31111
2,32,31111
1,2,31,2,311122

Summing up: 0+0+1+0+1+1+2=50+0+1+0+1+1+2=5.

problems.title: Maximum Polygon
problems.statementHtml:
Given an array a of length n, determine the lexicographically largest∗ subsequence† s of a such that s can be the side lengths of a polygon.

Recall that s can be the side lengths of a polygon if and only if |s|≥3 and

2⋅max(s1,s2,…,s|s|)<s1+s2+…+s|s|.

If no such subsequence s exists, print −1.

∗A sequence x is lexicographically smaller than a sequence y if and only if one of the following holds:

†A sequence x is a subsequence of a sequence y if x can be obtained from y by deleting several (possibly zero or all) elements.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer n (3≤n≤2⋅105) — the length of the array a.

The second line contains n integers a1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤109) — the array a.

It is guaranteed that the total sum of all values of n across all test cases does not exceed 2⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output the answer in the following format:

If the answer exists, output the following.

In the first line, output the integer k (1≤k≤n) — the length of the subsequence s.

In the second line, output k integers s1,s2,…,sk (1≤si≤109, s is a subsequence of a) — the subsequence s. Note that the desired output is the value, not the index.

Otherwise, output a single line with the integer −1.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, there are no subsequences that can be the side lengths of a polygon.

In the second test case, there are 2 subsequences that can be the side lengths of a polygon: 1,4,2,3 and 4,2,3. The latter is the lexicographically larger subsequence.

problems.title: Another Folding Strip
problems.statementHtml:
For an array b of length m, define f(b) as follows.

Consider a 1×m strip, where all cells initially have darkness 0. You want to transform it into a strip where the color at the i-th position has darkness bi. You can perform the following operation, which consists of two steps:

Let f(b) be the minimum number of operations required to achieve the desired configuration. It can be proven that the goal can always be achieved in a finite number of operations.

You are given an array a of length n. Evaluate

∑l=1n∑r=lnf(alal+1…ar)

modulo 998244353.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer n (1≤n≤2⋅105) — the length of the array a.

The second line contains n integers a1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤109) — denoting the array a.

It is guaranteed that the sum of all values of n across all test cases does not exceed 2⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the required sum modulo 998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case,

  • f(a1)=f(0)=0
  • f(a1a2)=f(01)=1
  • f(a1a2a3)=f(010)=1
  • f(a2)=f(1)=1
  • f(a2a3)=f(10)=1
  • f(a3)=f(0)=0

This sums up to 0+1+1+1+1+0=4

In the second test case, f(a1a2a3a4a5a6)=2. Here's one possible sequence of operations.

problems.title: AND x OR
problems.statementHtml:
Suppose you have two arrays cc and dd, each of length kk. The pair (c,d)(c,d) is called good if cc can be changed to dd by performing the following operation any number of times.

You are given two arrays aa and bb, both of length nn, containing nonnegative integers not exceeding mm.

You can perform two types of moves on these arrays any number of times:

Note that the elements of aa and bb may exceed mm at some point while performing the moves.

Find the minimum number of moves required to make the pair (a,b)(a,b) good.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (1≤n,m≤2⋅1061≤n,m≤2⋅106) — the length of arrays aa and bb, and the maximum possible value in these arrays, respectively.

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤m0≤ai≤m) — denoting the array aa.

The third line contains nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (0≤bi≤m0≤bi≤m) — denoting the array bb.

Additionally, it is guaranteed that the sum of all values of nn and the sum of all values of mm across all test cases do not exceed 2⋅1062⋅106.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the minimum number of moves required to make the pair (a,b)(a,b) good.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first case, we already have a=ba=b.

In the second case, we can perform move 22 on index i=2i=2 twice. The array bb becomes [8,8,32][8,8,32]. We can see that (a,b)(a,b) is now good.

In the third case, we can perform move 22 on index i=1i=1, then perform move 11 on index i=2i=2. It can be proven that you cannot make the pair (a,b)(a,b) good in fewer than 22 moves.

problems.title: RGB Walking
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a connected graph with nn vertices and mm bidirectional edges with weight not exceeding xx. The ii-th edge connects vertices uiui and vivi, has weight wiwi, and is assigned a color cici (1≤i≤m1≤i≤m, 1≤ui,vi≤n1≤ui,vi≤n). The color cici is either red, green, or blue. It is guaranteed that there is at least one edge of each color.

For a walk where vertices and edges may be repeated, let sr,sg,sbsr,sg,sb denote the sum of the weights of the red, green, and blue edges that the walk passes through, respectively. If an edge is traversed multiple times, each traversal is counted separately.

Find the minimum value of max(sr,sg,sb)−min(sr,sg,sb)max(sr,sg,sb)−min(sr,sg,sb) over all possible walks from vertex 11 to vertex nn.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains three integers nn, mm, and xx (4≤n≤2⋅1054≤n≤2⋅105, n−1≤m≤2⋅105n−1≤m≤2⋅105, 1≤x≤2⋅1051≤x≤2⋅105) — the number of vertices, the number of edges in the graph, and the upper bound on the weight of the edges, respectively.

The next mm lines each contain three integers ui,vi,wiui,vi,wi and a letter cici (1≤ui,vi≤n1≤ui,vi≤n, 1≤wi≤x1≤wi≤x), representing a bidirectional edge between vertices uiui and vivi with weight wiwi and color cici. The color cici is either 'r', 'g', or 'b', denoting red, green, and blue, respectively.

It is guaranteed that the graph is connected and contains at least one edge of each color. The graph may also contain multiple edges and self-loops.

Additionally, it is guaranteed that the total sum of all values of nn, the total sum of all values of mm, and the total sum of all values of xx across all test cases do not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105 individually.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the minimum value of max(sr,sg,sb)−min(sr,sg,sb)max(sr,sg,sb)−min(sr,sg,sb) over all walks from vertex 11 to vertex nn.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the optimal path is 1→2→3→41→2→3→4. The edges used are:

  • 1→21→2 (red, weight 22)
  • 2→32→3 (green, weight 33)
  • 3→43→4 (blue, weight 22)

We have sr=2sr=2, sg=3sg=3, and sb=2sb=2. Thus, the answer is 11.

In the second test case, one of the optimal paths is 1→1→2→1→2→3→41→1→2→1→2→3→4. The edges used are:

  • 1→11→1 (red, weight 11)
  • 1→21→2 (red, weight 11)
  • 2→12→1 (red, weight 11)
  • 1→21→2 (red, weight 11)
  • 2→32→3 (green, weight 44)
  • 3→43→4 (blue, weight 44)

We have sr=sg=sb=4sr=sg=sb=4. Thus, the answer is 00.

tutorial.contentHtml:
I hope everyone enjoyed the tasks, and thank you for participating.

Thank you to the coordinators and testers for suggesting solutions and modifications to the tasks, as I alone wouldn't be able to solve my own tasks or make it to how it is right now. Also thank you to them for dealing with me since July.

Please tell me in the comments if the editorial is written incorrectly or unintelligibly somewhere. I'm not the best at phrasing some things, and would appreciate amendments to the editorial.

2078A - Final Verdict

Hint

Something doesn't change after each operation.
